title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 establishes specifications for the coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States. The coins issued under this Act shall bear a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden. Each coin will have a designated value, the year 1995 inscribed, and the words "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins issued under this Act will be legal tender. The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. Selection of design for the coins. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. Issuance of coins. The Act authorizes the issuance of coins in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at a designated Mint facility. The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. Additionally, only one Mint facility in the United States may strike coins minted under this Act. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus surcharge. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount. Prepaid orders for the coins will be accepted by the Secretary. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount. Prepaid orders for the coins will be accepted by the Secretary prior to the issuance of such coins. Sales will include a surcharge of $10 per coin. General waiver of procurement regulations. No law governing procurement or public contracts applies to the procurement of goods or services necessary for carrying out the provisions of this Act. This section does not exempt anyone entering into a contract under this Act from complying with any law related to equal employment opportunity. Distribution of surcharges. Distribution of surcharges received by the Secretary from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. The Comptroller General has the right to examine books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures of amounts paid under section 8. The Act may be cited as the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies the coin details. The "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" authorizes the minting of up to 500,000 $1 coins made of 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins feature a design of a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender according to section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The coins minted under the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" feature designs of a rose and the Botanic Garden facade, with inscriptions including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. The Secretary must obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee before issuance. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at one designated Mint facility from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge, and design/issuance costs. Bulk sales will be available at a discount, prepaid orders accepted, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales are promptly paid to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General can examine the National Fund's books related to these payments.
